title: 107_hr1026
content: The Act titled "Increased Individual Retirement Accounts for All Act of 2001" increases the maximum contributions allowable to deductible, traditional, and Roth IRAs. The Act "Increased Individual Retirement Accounts for All Act of 2001" raises the maximum deduction amount from $2,000 to $5,000 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, individuals aged 50 or older can make catch-up contributions up to $7,500. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 was amended to increase the maximum deduction amount to $5,000 for taxable years after 2001. This amount will be adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 was amended to increase the maximum deduction amount to $5,000 for taxable years after 2001, adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. Section 408 of the Code was further amended to round amounts not multiples of $500 to the next higher multiple. Various sections were updated to reference the new maximum deduction amount under section 219(b)(1)(A). Section 408(j) and 408(p)(8) of the Internal Revenue Code were amended to update the dollar amount to the one in effect under section 219(b)(1)(A). These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. SEC. 25B introduces a nonrefundable credit for elective deferrals and IRA contributions by certain individuals. The nonrefundable credit introduced by SEC. 25B allows eligible individuals to receive a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year based on a percentage of qualified retirement savings contributions, with a reduction for certain retirement distributions received during the testing period. The testing period for certain retirement distributions includes the taxable year, the 2 preceding years, and the period after the taxable year. The applicable percentage for this section is determined according to a specific table. Adjusted Gross Income percentages are determined based on specific income ranges outlined in a table. Adjusted Gross Income percentages are determined based on specific income ranges outlined in a table. The table shows income brackets and corresponding percentages. An eligible individual, for this section, is defined as someone over 18 years old with at least $5,000 in gross income. Dependents and full-time students are not considered eligible individuals. For tax purposes, an eligible individual is someone over 18 with at least $5,000 in gross income, excluding dependents and full-time students. Qualified retirement savings contributions include various types of contributions to retirement plans. Special rules apply to distributions received by an individual's spouse. For tax purposes, an eligible individual is determined by joint filing status with a spouse. Adjusted gross income excludes specific sections. Qualified retirement savings contributions are not affected by the credit under this section. The section applies to taxable years before December 31, 2005. A new item is added to the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide an annual report to Congress on the number of individuals claiming the credit under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code. Additionally, a report on the impact of the credit on pension coverage must be submitted within 4 years of the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 focus on expanding pension coverage for low- and moderate-income workers, improving pension benefits, enhancing coverage quality, increasing workers' access to plans, and ensuring retirement security. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2000.
